clusters.title: Japan’s ruling party elects Sanae Takaichi as new leader, likely to become first female PM

items.title: Japan’s ruling party elects Sanae Takaichi as new leader, likely to become first female PM
Sanae Takaichi elected as new leader of Japan’s ruling party, likely to become 1st female PM
items.standfirst: In a country that ranks poorly internationally for gender equality, the new president of Japan's long-governing Liberal Democrats, and likely next prime minister, is an ultra-conservative star of a male-dominated party that critics call an obstacle to women's advancement.
items.content: In a country that ranks poorly internationally for gender equality, the new president of Japan's long-governing Liberal Democrats, and likely next prime minister, is an ultra-conservative star of a male-dominated party that critics call an obstacle to women's advancement.

items.title: Japan braces for shift to right under ‘Iron Lady’ fan Takaichi
items.standfirst: Sanae Takaichi, the pro-stimulus conservative poised to become Japan’s first female prime minister, is an energetic nationalist with a soft spot for the hard-nosed politics of Iron Lady Margaret Thatcher and the heavy metal music of Iron Maiden. In choosing the former economic security minister as…

items.title: Who Is Sanae Takaichi? Conservative Set To Be Japan's First Female Leader
items.standfirst: The newly elected leader of the Liberal Democratic Party is poised to become the country’s first female prime minister.
items.content: The newly elected leader of the Liberal Democratic Party is poised to become the country’s first female prime minister.

items.title: Japan's ruling party elects Sanae Takaichi as new leader, likely first female PM
items.standfirst: An admirer of former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Sanae Takaichi is a protege of the ultra-conservative vision of former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.
items.content: An admirer of former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Sanae Takaichi is a protege of the ultra-conservative vision of former Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.

items.content: Arch-conservative who models herself on Margaret Thatcher beats Shinjiro Koizumi in second-round party vote

items.title: Japan's ruling party elects Sanae Takaichi as leader, likely to become first female PM
items.standfirst: Japan's governing party on Saturday elected Sanae Takaichi, a hard-line ultra-conservative and China hawk, as its new leader, making her likely to become the country's first female prime minister.
items.content: Japan's governing party on Saturday elected Sanae Takaichi, a hard-line ultra-conservative and China hawk, as its new leader, making her likely to become the country's first female prime minister.(Image credit: Kim Kyung-Hoon)

items.title: Japan set for first female prime minister
items.standfirst: Japan could be about to have its first female prime minister, as a woman is elected leader of the governing party.
items.content: Japan could be about to have its first female prime minister, as a woman is elected leader of the governing party.

items.title: Japan poised to get first female PM after Sanae Takaichi wins ruling party leadership
items.standfirst: Margaret Thatcher admirer beat her more moderate rival to become leader of Liberal Democratic partyJapan is poised to get its first female prime minister after Sanae Takaichi was elected as leader of the governing Liberal Democratic party (LDP) – a victory that should lead to her being installed as the country’s new leader in the middle of the month.Takaichi, a rightwing politician who has voiced admiration for Margaret Thatcher in her quest to build a “strong and prosperous” Japan on the international stage, beat her moderate rival, Shinjiro Koizumi, in a runoff election at the LDP headquarters in Tokyo on Saturday. Continue reading...
items.content: Margaret Thatcher admirer beat her more moderate rival to become leader of Liberal Democratic partyJapan is poised to get its first female prime minister after Sanae Takaichi was elected as leader of the governing Liberal Democratic party (LDP) – a victory that should lead to her being installed as the country’s new leader in the middle of the month.Takaichi, a rightwing politician who has voiced admiration for Margaret Thatcher in her quest to build a “strong and prosperous” Japan on the international stage, beat her moderate rival, Shinjiro Koizumi, in a runoff election at the LDP headquarters in Tokyo on Saturday. Continue reading...

items.title: Sanae Takaichi set to become Japan's first female prime minister
items.standfirst: Takaichi is a long-time admirer of Margaret Thatcher, but many female voters do not see her as an advocate for progress.
items.content: Takaichi is a long-time admirer of Margaret Thatcher, but many female voters do not see her as an advocate for progress.

items.title: Japan’s LDP elects Takaichi as new leader, likely to be first female PM
items.standfirst: If elected, Takaichi will face a host of issues, including an ageing population and growing unease about immigration.
items.content: If elected, Takaichi will face a host of issues, including an ageing population and growing unease about immigration.

items.title: Japan is poised for its first-ever female prime minister
items.standfirst: Japan’s governing party elected Sanae Takaichi as its new leader on Saturday, setting her up to become the U.S. ally’s first female prime minister.
items.content: Japan’s governing party elected Sanae Takaichi as its new leader on Saturday, setting her up to become the U.S. ally’s first female prime minister.

items.title: Who are the candidates running to be Japan’s next prime minister?
items.standfirst: Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party is choosing its next leader on Saturday.
items.content: Japan's governing Liberal Democratic Party is choosing its next leader on Saturday.

items.title: Japan may be about to make history with its next prime minister
items.standfirst: Japan could end up with its first female prime minister or its youngest leader in more than a century after a party leadership election on Saturday.
items.content: Japan could end up with its first female prime minister or its youngest leader in more than a century after a party leadership election on Saturday.

ai_summary: Sanae Takaichi, an ultra-conservative, was elected leader of Japan's ruling party.
She is likely to become Japan's first female prime minister.
Takaichi is known for her admiration of Margaret Thatcher and heavy metal music.
She is considered a China hawk and a proponent of economic stimulus.
Her election may shift Japan's politics to the right.

clusters.title: Andrej Babis leads vote count in Czech parliamentary election
clusters.neutral_headline: Populist Billionaire Andrej Babis Wins Czech Election

items.title: Andrej Babis leads vote count in Czech parliamentary election
items.standfirst: Billionaire Andrej Babis's ANO party cruised to victory in the Czech Republic's parliamentary election on Saturday, raising the prospect of a government that would boost Europe's populist, anti-immigration camp and reduce support for Ukraine. "It is one of the greatest results ever for any party in the history of the modern Czech Republic", said Ian Willoughby, FRANCE 24 correspondent in Prague.
items.content: Billionaire Andrej Babis's ANO party cruised to victory in the Czech Republic's parliamentary election on Saturday, raising the prospect of a government that would boost Europe's populist, anti-immigration camp and reduce support for Ukraine. "It is one of the greatest results ever for any party in the history of the modern Czech Republic", said Ian Willoughby, FRANCE 24 correspondent in Prague.

items.title: Populist billionaire Andrej Babiš wins Czech parliamentary election
items.standfirst: With Babiš’s victory the Czech Republic looks set to join Hungary and Slovakia in refusing support for UkrainePopulist billionaire Andrej Babiš has won the Czech parliamentary election in a political comeback that puts the country on a course away from supporting Ukraine and towards Hungary and Slovakia, which have taken a pro-Russian path.With the votes from almost 98% of polling stations counted by the statistics office, Babiš’s ANO (YES) movement captured 35% of the vote followed by the pro-western coalition of the prime minister, Petr Fiala, with 23.0%. The coalition defeated Babiš in the 2021 election. Continue reading...
items.content: With Babiš’s victory the Czech Republic looks set to join Hungary and Slovakia in refusing support for UkrainePopulist billionaire Andrej Babiš has won the Czech parliamentary election in a political comeback that puts the country on a course away from supporting Ukraine and towards Hungary and Slovakia, which have taken a pro-Russian path.With the votes from almost 98% of polling stations counted by the statistics office, Babiš’s ANO (YES) movement captured 35% of the vote followed by the pro-western coalition of the prime minister, Petr Fiala, with 23.0%. The coalition defeated Babiš in the 2021 election. Continue reading...

items.title: Populist billionaire Andrej Babis’s party set to win Czech election
items.standfirst: With most votes tallied, Babis’s ANO party is ahead, but it appears set to fall short of a majority in parliament.
items.content: With most votes tallied, Babis’s ANO party is ahead, but it appears set to fall short of a majority in parliament.

items.title: Populist billionaire Andrej Babiš wins Czech parliamentary election
items.standfirst: His political comeback put the country on a course away from supporting Ukraine and toward Hungary and Slovakia, which have taken a pro-Russian path.
items.content: His political comeback put the country on a course away from supporting Ukraine and toward Hungary and Slovakia, which have taken a pro-Russian path.(Image credit: Petr David Josek)

items.title: 'Trumpist' billionaire Andrej Babis wins Czech parliamentary election
items.standfirst: Populist, billionaire and self-proclaimed "Trumpist" Andrej Babis won the Czech parliamentary election Saturday in a political comeback that put the country on a course away from supporting Ukraine and toward Hungary and Slovakia, which have taken a pro-Russian path.
items.content: Populist, billionaire and self-proclaimed "Trumpist" Andrej Babis won the Czech parliamentary election Saturday in a political comeback that put the country on a course away from supporting Ukraine and toward Hungary and Slovakia, which have taken a pro-Russian path.

items.title: Billionaire populist Andrej Babis' party wins Czech parliamentary election
items.standfirst: However, his ANO party falls short of an overall majority in preliminary results.
items.content: However, his ANO party falls short of an overall majority in preliminary results.

items.title: Populist billionaire Babis on track to win Czech election
Billionaire Babis's party on track to win Czech election
items.standfirst: Billionaire Andrej Babis's ANO party was on track to win the Czech Republic's parliamentary election on Saturday (October 4). FRANCE 24's Ian Willoughby tells us more.
items.content: Billionaire Andrej Babis's ANO party was on track to win the Czech Republic's parliamentary election on Saturday (October 4). FRANCE 24's Ian Willoughby tells us more.

items.title: Czech Billionaire on Track for Victory in Parliamentary Vote
Czechs head to the polls for final day of general elections
items.standfirst: Czechs began voting for a second and last day Saturday (October 4) in a general election in which the party of self-described "Trumpist" billionaire Andrej Babis is a frontrunner. FRANCE 24's Ian Willoughby tells us more.
items.content: Czechs began voting for a second and last day Saturday (October 4) in a general election in which the party of self-described "Trumpist" billionaire Andrej Babis is a frontrunner. FRANCE 24's Ian Willoughby tells us more.

ai_summary: Andrej Babis's ANO party won the Czech parliamentary election.
The victory may shift the country away from supporting Ukraine.
Babis is a self-proclaimed "Trumpist" and populist billionaire.
His party is expected to fall short of a majority in parliament.
The Czech Republic may align with Hungary and Slovakia.

clusters.title: ‘I feel like we are in a trap’: Gaza residents hopeful but wary of Trump’s plan
clusters.neutral_headline: Gaza Residents React to Trump's Peace Plan

items.title: ‘I feel like we are in a trap’: Gaza residents hopeful but wary of Trump’s plan
items.standfirst: Hamas’s agreement to release all hostages and surrender power hailed internationally as Israeli attacks continueWhen Arij al-Farra heard that Hamas had partially agreed to Donald Trump’s plan and that the US president had ordered Israel to stop bombing Gaza, the first thing she felt was a flicker of hope. The second thing she felt was an explosion. An Israeli aircraft had dropped a bomb close to her tent in Khan Younis, southern Gaza.Though it was luck that saved Farra from death, she took the attack as a bad omen for the prospects for peace in Gaza. Continue reading...
items.content: Hamas’s agreement to release all hostages and surrender power hailed internationally as Israeli attacks continueWhen Arij al-Farra heard that Hamas had partially agreed to Donald Trump’s plan and that the US president had ordered Israel to stop bombing Gaza, the first thing she felt was a flicker of hope. The second thing she felt was an explosion. An Israeli aircraft had dropped a bomb close to her tent in Khan Younis, southern Gaza.Though it was luck that saved Farra from death, she took the attack as a bad omen for the prospects for peace in Gaza. Continue reading...

items.title: US-backed peace plan for Gaza: What to expect from further negotiations?
items.standfirst: Israel's army said Saturday (October 4) that it would advance preparations for the first phase of Donald Trump's plan to end the war in Gaza. Two envoys of US President Donald Trump headed to Egypt on Saturday to discuss the release of hostages in Gaza, while Israeli forces launched deadly strikes across the territory. For more analysis on US-backed plan, FRANCE 24's Catherine Viette is joined by Hussein Ibish, senior resident scholar at the Arab Gulf States Insitute in Washington.
items.content: Israel's army said Saturday (October 4) that it would advance preparations for the first phase of Donald Trump's plan to end the war in Gaza. Two envoys of US President Donald Trump headed to Egypt on Saturday to discuss the release of hostages in Gaza, while Israeli forces launched deadly strikes across the territory. For more analysis on US-backed plan, FRANCE 24's Catherine Viette is joined by Hussein Ibish, senior resident scholar at the Arab Gulf States Insitute in Washington.

items.title: Israel says it prepares for first phase of Trump plan after striking Gaza overnight
items.standfirst: Israel’s army said it would advance preparations for the first phase of US President Donald Trump’s plan to end the war in Gaza and return all the remaining hostages. The news came after Israel launched dozens of air strikes and artillery attacks on Gaza City overnight, Gaza’s civil defence agency said.
items.content: Israel’s army said it would advance preparations for the first phase of US President Donald Trump’s plan to end the war in Gaza and return all the remaining hostages. The news came after Israel launched dozens of air strikes and artillery attacks on Gaza City overnight, Gaza’s civil defence agency said.

items.title: Trump's peace plan: Residents in Gaza and in Israel react to Hamas's response
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner and a senior US envoy are heading to Egypt Saturday (October 4) to finalize hostage release details, a White House official said after Hamas reacted positively to a peace plan to end two years of war.
items.content: President Donald Trump's son-in-law Jared Kushner and a senior US envoy are heading to Egypt Saturday (October 4) to finalize hostage release details, a White House official said after Hamas reacted positively to a peace plan to end two years of war.

items.title: Israel orders military to halt Gaza City campaign but continues strikes on the territory
items.standfirst: IDF says it was directed to ready for first part of Donald Trump’s plan to end war in Gaza after Hamas agrees to release hostagesThe Israeli military has been ordered to halt its campaign in Gaza City by its political leadership, Israeli army radio reported on Saturday, while it was preparing for the first phase of Donald Trump’s plan to end the war in Gaza and release all hostages.In a statement, the Israeli military said it was directed to “advance readiness” for the first part of the Trump plan. Army radio reported that operations in Gaza would be reduced to “the minimum” with troops meant only to carry out defensive strikes. Continue reading...
items.content: IDF says it was directed to ready for first part of Donald Trump’s plan to end war in Gaza after Hamas agrees to release hostagesThe Israeli military has been ordered to halt its campaign in Gaza City by its political leadership, Israeli army radio reported on Saturday, while it was preparing for the first phase of Donald Trump’s plan to end the war in Gaza and release all hostages.In a statement, the Israeli military said it was directed to “advance readiness” for the first part of the Trump plan. Army radio reported that operations in Gaza would be reduced to “the minimum” with troops meant only to carry out defensive strikes. Continue reading...

items.title: Hamas' Hardline Ally Reacts to Trump's Gaza Plan
items.standfirst: Palestinian Islamic Jihad has backed Hamas’ response to President Donald Trump's 20-point Gaza peace plan.
items.content: Palestinian Islamic Jihad has backed Hamas’ response to President Donald Trump's 20-point Gaza peace plan.

items.title: Can the US-backed peace 'sketch' for Gaza succeed?
items.standfirst: Israel's army said Saturday (October 4) that it would advance preparations for the first phase of US President Donald Trump's plan to end the war in Gaza. US President called to halt bombardments following Hamas's acceptance of some elements of his plan. But Israel launched air strikes on Gaza City overnight, Gaza’s civil defence agency said. For more analysis on that plan, William Hilderbrandt is joined by Scott Lucas, professor of International Politics at University College Dublin Clinton Institute.
items.content: Israel's army said Saturday (October 4) that it would advance preparations for the first phase of US President Donald Trump's plan to end the war in Gaza. US President called to halt bombardments following Hamas's acceptance of some elements of his plan. But Israel launched air strikes on Gaza City overnight, Gaza’s civil defence agency said. For more analysis on that plan, William Hilderbrandt is joined by Scott Lucas, professor of International Politics at University College Dublin Clinton Institute.

items.title: US-backed peace plan for Gaza: What we know so far
items.standfirst: Israel's army said Saturday (October 4) that it would advance preparations for the first phase of US President Donald Trump's plan to end the war in Gaza. US President Donald Trump called to halt bombardments following Hamas's acceptance of some elements of his plan. But Israel launched dozens of air strikes and artillery attacks on Gaza City overnight, Gaza’s civil defence agency said Saturday. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky tells us more about what we know so far.
items.content: Israel's army said Saturday (October 4) that it would advance preparations for the first phase of US President Donald Trump's plan to end the war in Gaza. US President Donald Trump called to halt bombardments following Hamas's acceptance of some elements of his plan. But Israel launched dozens of air strikes and artillery attacks on Gaza City overnight, Gaza’s civil defence agency said Saturday. FRANCE 24's Noga Tarnopolsky tells us more about what we know so far.

items.title: Donald Trump orders Israel to ‘immediately’ stop bombing Gaza as Hamas agrees to free hostages
items.standfirst: Palestinian militant group accepts part of US president’s plan but seeks further negotiations on many termsDonald Trump ordered Israel to “immediately” stop bombing Gaza as he welcomed Hamas’s partial acceptance of his ultimatum to end the nearly two-year war.Hamas has agreed to release all hostages in return for Palestinian prisoners held in Israeli jails, as well as surrender governing power in the Gaza Strip, in accordance with Trump’s plan. Continue reading...
items.content: Palestinian militant group accepts part of US president’s plan but seeks further negotiations on many termsDonald Trump ordered Israel to “immediately” stop bombing Gaza as he welcomed Hamas’s partial acceptance of his ultimatum to end the nearly two-year war.Hamas has agreed to release all hostages in return for Palestinian prisoners held in Israeli jails, as well as surrender governing power in the Gaza Strip, in accordance with Trump’s plan. Continue reading...

items.title: Egypt foreign minister urges Hamas to accept Trump Gaza plan and disarm
items.standfirst: Hamas reportedly split on response to deal as US president sets Sunday deadline for militant group to replyEgypt and Qatar are working to convince Hamas to accept Donald Trump’s ultimatum to end the war in Gaza, Egypt’s foreign minister has said, as Trump gave a Sunday deadline to reply.Badr Abdelatty said the time had come for Hamas to disarm, and that Israel should be given no excuse to continue its offensive in Gaza, where it killed another 28 Palestinians on Friday. Continue reading...
items.content: Hamas reportedly split on response to deal as US president sets Sunday deadline for militant group to replyEgypt and Qatar are working to convince Hamas to accept Donald Trump’s ultimatum to end the war in Gaza, Egypt’s foreign minister has said, as Trump gave a Sunday deadline to reply.Badr Abdelatty said the time had come for Hamas to disarm, and that Israel should be given no excuse to continue its offensive in Gaza, where it killed another 28 Palestinians on Friday. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Hamas agreed to parts of a peace plan proposed by Donald Trump.
The plan included the release of hostages and Israeli withdrawal.
Israeli forces launched strikes in Gaza after Hamas's response.
US envoys headed to Egypt to finalize hostage release details.
Residents in Gaza expressed hope but also wariness of the plan.

clusters.title: Russian strike hits train station in Ukraine, killing at least one
clusters.neutral_headline: Russian Strike Hits Ukrainian Railway Station

items.title: Russian strike hits train station in Ukraine, killing at least one
items.standfirst: Russian drones struck trains at a station in Ukraine's northern Sumy region, killing one person and injuring at least 30 others, officials said on Saturday (October 4), with Ukraine's foreign minister accusing Moscow of deliberately hitting passenger trains.
items.content: Russian drones struck trains at a station in Ukraine's northern Sumy region, killing one person and injuring at least 30 others, officials said on Saturday (October 4), with Ukraine's foreign minister accusing Moscow of deliberately hitting passenger trains.

items.title: Person killed in drone attack as Ukraine accuses Russia of targeting passenger trains
items.standfirst: Two trains were hit in Ukraine’s northern Sumy region, killing one and injuring about 30 others, officials sayTwo Russian drones struck trains at a station in Ukraine’s northern Sumy region, killing one person and injuring about 30 others, officials said on Saturday, with Ukraine’s foreign minister accusing Moscow of deliberately hitting passenger trains.“A brutal Russian drone strike on the railway station in Shostka, Sumy region,” wrote the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, on Telegram, posting a video of a wrecked, burning passenger carriage and others with their windows blown out. Continue reading...
items.content: Two trains were hit in Ukraine’s northern Sumy region, killing one and injuring about 30 others, officials sayTwo Russian drones struck trains at a station in Ukraine’s northern Sumy region, killing one person and injuring about 30 others, officials said on Saturday, with Ukraine’s foreign minister accusing Moscow of deliberately hitting passenger trains.“A brutal Russian drone strike on the railway station in Shostka, Sumy region,” wrote the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, on Telegram, posting a video of a wrecked, burning passenger carriage and others with their windows blown out. Continue reading...

items.title: At least 30 injured in Russian strike on railway station, Zelensky says
items.standfirst: Preliminary reports indicate that train staff and passengers were at the site of the strike, he says.
items.content: Preliminary reports indicate that train staff and passengers were at the site of the strike, he says.

items.title: Russia strikes hit two passenger trains in northern Ukraine, injuring dozens
items.standfirst: Dozens were injured after a Russian drone attack hit a Ukrainian railway station on Saturday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said. Moscow is stepping up its strikes on Ukraine's railway network, which is essential for military transport, targeting it almost every day for the past two months.
items.content: Dozens were injured after a Russian drone attack hit a Ukrainian railway station on Saturday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said. Moscow is stepping up its strikes on Ukraine's railway network, which is essential for military transport, targeting it almost every day for the past two months.

items.title: Russian attack on passenger train in Ukraine’s Sumy kills one, injures 30
items.standfirst: President Zelenskyy condemns Moscow's latest strike on Ukraine's railway infrastructure.
items.content: President Zelenskyy condemns Moscow's latest strike on Ukraine's railway infrastructure.

items.title: One dead and several injured after Russian drone strike on Ukrainian railway station
items.standfirst: At least one person has died, and several others injured, in a Russian drone strike on a Ukrainian railway station, the country's state emergency services has said.
items.content: At least one person has died, and several others injured, in a Russian drone strike on a Ukrainian railway station, the country's state emergency services has said.

ai_summary: A Russian drone strike hit a railway station in Ukraine's Sumy region.
One person was killed, and approximately 30 others were injured.
Ukrainian President Zelenskyy condemned the attack.
The strike targeted passenger trains, according to Ukraine.
Russia is increasing strikes on Ukraine's railway infrastructure.

clusters.title: Germany’s Munich Airport reopens after closures due to drone sightings
clusters.neutral_headline: Munich Airport Reopens After Drone Sightings

items.title: Germany’s Munich Airport reopens after closures due to drone sightings
items.standfirst: Germany's Munich Airport reopened Saturday morning after authorities shut it down the night before for the second time in less than 24 hours after two additional drone sightings, officials said. The closures are the latest after mysterious drone overflights in the airspace of European Union member…
items.content: Germany's Munich Airport reopened Saturday morning after authorities shut it down the night before for the second time in less than 24 hours after two additional drone sightings, officials said. The closures are the latest after mysterious drone overflights in the airspace of European Union member…

items.title: Munich airport resumes operations after more drone sightings halted flights
items.standfirst: The German airport says that 46 flights had been cancelled or delayed, affecting 6,500 passengers.
items.content: The German airport says that 46 flights had been cancelled or delayed, affecting 6,500 passengers.

items.title: Flights resume 'progressively' at Munich airport after second drone scare
items.standfirst: Flights resumed "progressively" on Saturday (October 4) at Munich airport, but delays were expected after a drone scare caused a second shutdown in as many days, affecting over 6,500 passengers, the operator said.
items.content: Flights resumed "progressively" on Saturday (October 4) at Munich airport, but delays were expected after a drone scare caused a second shutdown in as many days, affecting over 6,500 passengers, the operator said.

items.title: Munich airport resumes flights after suspected drones force second closure in 24 hours
items.standfirst: Flights were suspended for several hours on Friday night, with around 6,500 passengers affected.
items.content: Flights were suspended for several hours on Friday night, with around 6,500 passengers affected.

items.title: Munich airport reopens after drone sightings force closure
items.standfirst: Dozens of flights were cancelled or redirected at Munich International Airport after drone sightings.
items.content: Dozens of flights were cancelled or redirected at Munich International Airport after drone sightings.

ai_summary: Munich Airport reopened after multiple drone sightings.
Flights were suspended for a second time in two days.
Over 6,500 passengers were affected by the closures.
Dozens of flights were canceled or redirected.
Delays were expected as flights resumed progressively.

clusters.title: Police make more than 440 arrests at Palestine Action protest in London
clusters.neutral_headline: More Than 400 Arrests at Palestine Action Protest

items.title: Police make more than 440 arrests at Palestine Action protest in London
items.standfirst: Officers arrest activists at silent vigil in support of banned organisation, as demos go ahead despite PM’s pleasPolice have made more than 440 arrests in London at what organisers hoped would be the biggest demonstration so far against a ban on the proscribed organisation Palestine Action.Officers began arresting demonstrators at the silent vigil in support of the group, which has been classed by the UK government as a terror organisation since July this year. Continue reading...
items.content: Officers arrest activists at silent vigil in support of banned organisation, as demos go ahead despite PM’s pleasPolice have made more than 440 arrests in London at what organisers hoped would be the biggest demonstration so far against a ban on the proscribed organisation Palestine Action.Officers began arresting demonstrators at the silent vigil in support of the group, which has been classed by the UK government as a terror organisation since July this year. Continue reading...

items.title: More than 400 arrests at Palestine Action protests in London
items.standfirst: Demonstrations went ahead despite calls from politicians and police leaders for the protests to be postponed in wake of the Manchester synagogue attack.
items.content: Demonstrations went ahead despite calls from politicians and police leaders for the protests to be postponed in wake of the Manchester synagogue attack.

items.title: More than 400 arrested in London as pro-Palestine protest goes ahead despite pleas
items.standfirst: More than 400 people have been arrested over protests supporting the proscribed group Palestine Action, as demonstrators defied calls to reconsider in the wake of the Manchester synagogue terror attack.
items.content: More than 400 people have been arrested over protests supporting the proscribed group Palestine Action, as demonstrators defied calls to reconsider in the wake of the Manchester synagogue terror attack.

ai_summary: Over 400 arrests were made at a Palestine Action protest in London.
The protest supported the proscribed group Palestine Action.
Demonstrators defied calls to postpone the protest.
The demonstration took place despite the Manchester synagogue attack.
Police arrested activists at a silent vigil.

clusters.title: Hegseth says four killed in US strike on alleged drug boat off Venezuelan coast
clusters.neutral_headline: US Strike on Boat off Venezuela Kills Four

items.title: Hegseth says four killed in US strike on alleged drug boat off Venezuelan coast
items.standfirst: Pentagon chief says strike – fourth by US military in recent weeks – targeted boat with ‘substantial amounts’ of drugsThe United States carried out a strike against an alleged drug-trafficking boat on Friday that killed four people, US defense secretary Pete Hegseth said, a day after the Trump administration told Congress it was entering a new “non-international armed conflict” with cartels.The strike, which Hegseth said he directed on Donald Trump’s orders, appears to be at least the fourth in recent weeks. Hegseth gave few details about the boat or the evidence that it was carrying narcotics, other than saying the US had confirmed it was carrying drugs. Continue reading...
items.content: Pentagon chief says strike – fourth by US military in recent weeks – targeted boat with ‘substantial amounts’ of drugsThe United States carried out a strike against an alleged drug-trafficking boat on Friday that killed four people, US defense secretary Pete Hegseth said, a day after the Trump administration told Congress it was entering a new “non-international armed conflict” with cartels.The strike, which Hegseth said he directed on Donald Trump’s orders, appears to be at least the fourth in recent weeks. Hegseth gave few details about the boat or the evidence that it was carrying narcotics, other than saying the US had confirmed it was carrying drugs. Continue reading...

items.content: U.S. forces carried out a strike on an alleged drug-smuggling boat off the coast of Venezuela on Friday, killing four people, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said.

items.title: Four killed in latest US strike on alleged drug vessel near Venezuela
items.standfirst: Donald Trump says the boat was carrying enough drugs to kill thousands of people.
items.content: Donald Trump says the boat was carrying enough drugs to kill thousands of people.

items.title: Trump officials push claim that US in ‘armed conflict’ with drug cartels
items.standfirst: Administration attempts to justify strikes on alleged Venezuelan drug boats by claiming US under ‘armed attack’The Trump administration is trying to justify strikes on alleged Venezuelan drug boats by advancing a novel legal theory that the US is now in a “non-international armed conflict”, according to a person familiar with a notification to Congress.The notification was provided by senior Pentagon officials as part of an attempt to explain the Trump administration’s legal arguments for the strikes, including a classified briefing to members of the Senate armed services committee on Wednesday. Continue reading...
items.content: Administration attempts to justify strikes on alleged Venezuelan drug boats by claiming US under ‘armed attack’The Trump administration is trying to justify strikes on alleged Venezuelan drug boats by advancing a novel legal theory that the US is now in a “non-international armed conflict”, according to a person familiar with a notification to Congress.The notification was provided by senior Pentagon officials as part of an attempt to explain the Trump administration’s legal arguments for the strikes, including a classified briefing to members of the Senate armed services committee on Wednesday. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The US carried out a strike on an alleged drug-trafficking boat.
The strike occurred off the coast of Venezuela.
Four people were killed in the US strike.
The Trump administration claims it is in "armed conflict" with cartels.
The US is attempting to justify strikes on Venezuelan drug boats.

items.standfirst: US treasurer says officials looking at drafts for country’s 250th anniversary featuring president with raised fistTo commemorate the 250th anniversary of the US’s independence, the treasury department is mulling production of a $1 coin displaying Donald Trump with a clenched first under an American flag and the words “fight, fight, fight”.The words overtly reference what Trump said immediately after narrowly surviving an assassination attempt four months before he won a second presidency. items.title: Hamas agrees to release all Israeli hostages, conditions pending
items.standfirst: Hamas said it has agreed to release all Israeli hostages, alive or dead, as long as “the field conditions for the exchange are met” and expressed willingness to negotiate through mediators on President Donald Trump’s plan for peace in the Middle East

items.title: Costco to sell weight-loss drugs such as Ozempic and Wegovy at half-price
items.standfirst: The move comes as GLP-1 drug prices have soared as supply continues to be increasingly limitedCostco has struck an agreement with drugmaker Novo Nordisk to make anti-obesity GLP-1 medications such as Ozempic and Wegovy available to its members at roughly half the usual cost.Through the store’s prescription program, members with a valid prescription can buy a four-week supply of the injectables for $499. The offer is available only to those paying out of pocket, since many insurers still do not cover these medications. Continue reading...

items.title: PitchBook: VCs have invested $192.7B in AI startups so far this year, putting 2025 on track to be the first year when 50%+ of VC funding goes to the AI industry
AI Is Dominating 2025 VC Investing, Pulling in $192.7 Billion
items.standfirst: Venture capitalists poured $192.7 billion into AI startups so far this year — setting new global records and putting 2025 on track to be the first year where more than half of total VC dollars went into the industry, according to data provider PitchBook.

items.title: Two children killed and two critically injured in shooting near Houston
items.standfirst: A 13-year-old and a four-year-old died in shooting as police say all parties involved have been detainedTwo children were killed and two more were critically injured in a shooting early on Saturday near the Houston suburb of Angleton, Texas, authorities said.The Brazoria county sheriff’s office said in a Facebook post that deputies responded to reports of the shooting and found two children, ages 13 and four, fatally shot. Two other children, aged eight and nine, were flown by medical helicopter to a hospital and were in critical condition. Continue reading...

clusters.title: ICE wants to build a 24/7 social media surveillance team
clusters.neutral_headline: ICE Wants to Build Out a 24/7 Social Media Surveillance Team

items.title: ICE wants to build a 24/7 social media surveillance team
items.standfirst: ICE plans to hire contractors to scan platforms to target people for deportation.
items.content: United States immigration authorities are moving to dramatically expand their social media surveillance, with plans to hire nearly 30 contractors to sift through posts, photos, and messages—raw material to be transformed into intelligence for deportation raids and arrests. Federal contracting records reviewed by WIRED show that the agency is seeking private vendors to run a multiyear surveillance program out of two of its little-known targeting centers. The program envisions stationing nearly 30 private analysts at Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) facilities in Vermont and Southern California. Their job: Scour Facebook, TikTok, Instagram, YouTube, and other platforms, converting posts and profiles into fresh leads for enforcement raids. The initiative is still at the request-for-information stage, a step agencies use to gauge interest from contractors before an official bidding process. But draft planning documents show the scheme is ambitious: ICE wants a contractor capable of staffing the centers around the clock, constantly processing cases on tight deadlines, and supplying the agency with the latest and greatest subscription-based surveillance software.Read full article Comments

items.title: ICE Wants to Build Out a 24/7 Social Media Surveillance Team
items.standfirst: Documents show that ICE plans to hire dozens of contractors to scan X, Facebook, TikTok, and other platforms to target people for deportation.
items.content: Documents show that ICE plans to hire dozens of contractors to scan X, Facebook, TikTok, and other platforms to target people for deportation.

ai_summary: ICE plans to hire contractors for social media surveillance.
The goal is to target individuals for deportation.
Contractors will scan platforms like X, Facebook, and TikTok.

items.title: Cyberattack could leave Japan without its most popular beer
items.standfirst: Japan could soon be running out of Asahi, the East Asian nation’s most popular beer, following a devastating cyberattack Monday that has brought its factories to a halt.
items.content: Japan could soon be running out of Asahi, the East Asian nation’s most popular beer, following a devastating cyberattack Monday that has brought its factories to a halt.

items.title: Japan days away from running out of Asahi Super Dry due to cyber attack – reports
items.standfirst: The attack forced the company to halt production at most of its 30 factories nationwide, including those producing its signature beerThe Asahi group, Japan’s biggest brewery, is reportedly just days away from running out of its most popular beer, as it struggles to recover from a cyber-attack that caused a system outage.The ransomware attack, reported on Monday, forced the company to halt production at most of its 30 factories nationwide, including those producing it signature mass-market lager Asahi Super Dry. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

ai_summary: A cyberattack has halted production at Asahi breweries in Japan.
Japan's most popular beer, Asahi, may soon be unavailable.
The attack forced the company to halt production at most factories.
